questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? Headache Blurred vision Persistent pedal oedema Epigastric pain
Urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: Growth of 10^3 coliform in suprapubic sample

options.label: B
options.text: Growth of 10^5 coliform in voided urine sample

options.label: D
options.text: Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test

questions.correct_answer: B. Growth of 10^5 coliform in voided urine sample

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop warfarin and start LMWH
questions.explanation:
Medicine

FDA category

Adverse effects

Teratogenic

Use during lactation

Remark

Vitamin K antagonists (warfarin)

X

Teratogenicity, fetal bleeding complications

Yes

Allowed: Small amounts of metabolites pass into breast milk

-

Heparin (UFH)

C

Bone demineralization, osteoporosis, fractures in mother, risk of HIT

No

Allowed

-

LMWH

B

Lower risk of HIT and osteoporosis than UFH

No

Allowed

-

Danaparoid

B

-

No

Allowed

-

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL, and thus, she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146 mg/dl, and HbA1c was 7.6%. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Maturity onset diabetes of the young

questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

Gestational Diabetes

Pre-existing Diabetes

Timing

During pregnancy

Present before conception

Criteria

Fasting Plasma glucose

92 mg/dL

126 mg/dL (on two occasions)

1-hour plasma glucose

180 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (with hyperglycemic symptoms)

2-hour plasma glucose

153 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (during an OGTT in asymptomatic individuals)

HbA1c

≥5.7-6.4%

≥6.5%

Management

Resolves after delivery.

Requires intensive management before and during pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old woman who is pregnant for the first time, currently at 25 weeks gestation, and experiencing pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, along with nausea and vomiting for the past two days? Her blood pressure is 104/72 mm Hg, heart rate is 72 bpm, and she has generalized swelling. A peripheral smear shows hemolysis, and the following lab values are provided:Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3 Platelet count: 62000/mm3 Hematocrit: 26% AST: 90 IU/L
questions.explanation:
Haemolysis
  • Abnormal peripheral blood smear (Hemolysis)
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH > 600 IU/L)
  • Elevated bilirubin (≥ 1.2 mg/dL)
  • Decreased serum haptoglobin

Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Elevated (AST & ALT > 70 IU/L)

Low Platelet Count
  • Platelets < 100,000/μL

Mississippi Triple Class System

Class I (severe)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets <50 x 109 /L

Class II (moderate)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 50-100 x 109 /L

Class III (mild)
  • AST & ALT > 40 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 100-150 x 109 /L

Condition

HELLP Syndrome

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)

Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP)

Main Characteristics

Hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells), Elevated liver enzymes, Low Platelet count

Buildup of fat in the liver, liver dysfunction

Impaired bile flow, elevated bile acids, itching

Occurrence

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can also occur postpartum

Typically occurs in the third trimester

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can occur earlier

Symptoms

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, edema

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, malaise

Intense itching, especially on palms and soles

Risk to Mother

Can lead to serious complications such as liver rupture, liver failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Can lead to liver failure, coagulopathy, and other complications

Generally uncomfortable but usually does not pose a significant threat to the mother's overall health

Risk to Fetus

Can lead to fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, stillbirth, placental abruption

Can lead to fetal distress, preterm birth, and stillbirth

Increased risk of adverse fetal outcomes, such as preterm birth or stillbirth

Management

Immediate medical attention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Urgent medical intervention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Symptom relief, monitoring of bile acid levels, early delivery may be considered

Complications

Liver rupture, liver failure, DIC, maternal and fetal mortality

Liver failure, coagulopathy, maternal and fetal mortality

Increased risk of preterm birth, fetal distress, stillbirth

HELLP Syndrome

Risk Factors
  • History of preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome
  • Multiparity
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Chronic hypertension

Clinical Features
  • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Malaise
  • Headache & visual disturbances
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria

Complications

Mother:

  • Liver hematoma or rupture
  • Acute renal failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Placental abruption

Fetus:

  • Preterm birth
  • IUGR or Stillbirth

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are associated with oligohydramnios?
questions.explanation:
Causes

Polyhydramnios

Oligohydramnios
Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Renal agenesis
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Fetal growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Amnion nodosum
Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Preeclampsia
  • Placental insufficiency
Placental Factors Chorioangioma Placental abruption

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female is carrying monochorionic diamniotic twins. On ultrasound examination, there is evidence of polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other. What is the most likely complication?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage I

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II

Severe oligohydramnios in the donor twin with no visible bladder.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent/reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins.

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise.

Stage V

Demise of one or both twins.

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? IADPSG: International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group
What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity?

options.label: A
options.text: 2 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

options.label: B
options.text: 2 doses of 12 mg given 24 hours apart

options.label: C
options.text: 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

options.label: D
options.text: 4 doses of 12 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.correct_answer: C. 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.text: Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? Ultrasonography MRI Angiography X-ray
questions.explanation:
Placenta accreta spectrum

Description

Placenta accreta

Villi is firmly adherent to the endometrium

Placenta increta

Villi invades the myometrium

Placenta percreta

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta
  • Remove as much placenta as possible.
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding.

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy.
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics.
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy.

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except:

options.label: A
options.text: Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

options.label: B
options.text: Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels, and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis, and hemorrhage and organ damage seen in preeclampsia

options.label: D
options.text: Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in sFlt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.correct_answer: A. Prostaglandins play an important role; Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostaglandin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
questions.explanation:
Abnormal Trophoblastic Invasion

Incomplete remodeling of spiral arteries → Narrow, high-resistance vessels → Reduced placental perfusion → Hypoxia.

Endothelial Dysfunction

sFlt-1 and endoglin release → Inhibition of VEGF and PIGF → Reduced NO production → Vasoconstriction, increased vascular permeability (proteinuria, edema). (Option B ruled out)

Imbalance in Angiogenic Factors

Increased sFlt-1, decreased VEGF and PIGF → Impaired vascular repair and angiogenesis → Endothelial injury. (Option D ruled out)

Oxidative Stress and Inflammation

Hypoxia-reoxygenation injury → ROS and pro-inflammatory cytokines → Endothelial damage, pro-thrombotic state.

Vasoconstriction and Platelet Aggregation

Decreased PGI2 (vasodilator) and increased TXA2 (vasoconstrictor) → Systemic vasoconstriction, microvascular thrombosis.

Multi-Organ Ischemia and Damage

Vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction → Reduced blood flow to:

  • Kidneys: Proteinuria (glomerular endotheliosis).
  • Liver: Hepatic ischemia, HELLP syndrome.
  • Brain: Cerebral edema, seizures (eclampsia).
  • Placenta: Fetal growth restriction, abruption. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: What of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section? Bard-Parker blade Doyen's retractor Cusco's speculum Allis forceps Shirodkar's uterine clamp Green Armytage forceps

A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management? LMWH- Low molecular weight heparin

options.label: D
options.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop warfarin and start LMWH

questions.text: What is the maternal condition that can cause the observed findings in the baby as presented below?
In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Definition

A rare, life-threatening liver disorder that occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy, characterised by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes.

Risk Factors
  • First pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Male fetus
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Maternal obesity
  • Prior history of AFLP

Clinical Features
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice
  • Malaise and fatigue
  • Anorexia
  • Polydipsia and polyuria
  • Ascites (rare)

Investigation

  • Elevated AST, ALT
  • Elevated bilirubin
  • Hypofibrinogenemia
  • Prolonged clotting time
  • High D-dimer
  • Hypocholesterolemia
  • Microscopy: Microvesicular fatty infiltration

Complications
  • Liver failure
  • Renal failure
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Encephalopathy

Management
  • Immediate delivery of the baby (definitive treatment)
  • Supportive care for the mother: IV fluids, glucose infusion, and blood products for coagulopathy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who is pregnant with twins conceived through in vitro fertilization. She is a first-time mother and has reached 38 weeks of gestation. During an antenatal checkup, it was discovered that the first twin is in a breech position, and the mother's blood pressure has been consistently higher than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions, accompanied by grade 1+ proteinuria. What further actions should be taken?

options.label: A
options.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises

options.label: C
options.text: Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: Which of the following tests is utilized in contemporary obstetrics for monitoring the fetus of a mother who is Rh-negative and sensitized?
questions.correct_answer: D. MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

questions.text: What antenatal complication can be anticipated in the mother of the first baby, considering the second baby is a healthy newborn?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Macrosomia

Large birth weight of the baby (over 4,000 grams or 8 pounds 13 ounces), which can increase delivery complications.

Shoulder dystocia

Difficulty delivering the baby's shoulders after the head is delivered, which can lead to birth injuries and complications.

Neonatal hypoglycemia

Low blood sugar levels in the newborn due to elevated insulin levels during pregnancy.

Preterm birth

Delivery of the baby before 37 weeks of gestation, which increases the risk of health problems for the baby.

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)

A breathing disorder in premature babies due to immature lungs.

Jaundice

A yellowing of the baby's skin and eyes caused by high bilirubin levels.

Preeclampsia

High blood pressure and organ damage in the mother during pregnancy.

Type 2 diabetes later in life

Increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes for both the mother and the child later in life.

Increased risk of obesity and metabolic syndrome

Greater likelihood of the mother and child developing obesity and metabolic disorders.

questions.text: During a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation, a pregnant woman's abdominal examination showed that the size of her uterus was equivalent to that of a 16-week gestation. Additionally, an ultrasound detected the presence of oligohydramnios. What is the probable cause for these findings?

A 29-year-old G2P1 came to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent OGTT (75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours glucose at 180 mg/dl. Which of the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Induce labor due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anaemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant, as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 gm%. When should the iron supplements be started for her?
questions.explanation:
Anaemia management protocol for pregnant women

Target Group

Pregnant women registered for antenatal care

Screening and Periodicity

By health service provider at every ANC checkup

Degree

Of anaemia

First Level of Treatment

Follow-up

If No Improvement

Mild anaemia (Hb 10–10.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance.
  • Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose
  • Refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) if Hb <1 g/dl increases after one month of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

 

Moderate anaemia (Hb 7–9.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases.
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance. Monthly Hb estimation. Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose.
  • Refer to FRU/DH if Hb <1 g/dl increases after two months of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Severe anaemia (Hb 5.0–6.9 g/dl)
  • Managed by the medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH.
  • Treatment with IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxymaltose.
  • Immediate hospitalization in the third trimester is recommended at a higher facility.
  • Monthly or as prescribed by the medical officer
  • Follow treatment protocol as prescribed by the medical officer

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. She has a history of epilepsy and has been on anti-epileptic medication for the past 5 years. Which of the following statements regarding folic acid supplementation in patients on anti-epileptic drugs is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The daily requirement of folic acid is 400 mcg/day

options.label: B
options.text: The daily requirement of folic acid is 4 mg/day

options.label: C
options.text: The daily requirement of folic acid is 1 mg/day

options.label: D
options.text: The daily requirement of folic acid is 500 mcg/day

questions.correct_answer: B. The daily requirement of folic acid is 4 mg/day

questions.text: A 17-week pregnant woman presents with hypertension, with blood pressure measurements of 140/94 mmHg initially and 144/90 mmHg four hours later. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Hypertension in Obstetrics

Gestational
  • BP>140/90 (5th Korotkoff sound to record diastolic BP)
  • After 20 weeks ->2 occasions - 6 hours apart
  • Previously normotensive women
  • Also called transient hypertension
  • After delivery within 12 weeks BP is normal again

Preeclampsia
  • Proteinuria ≥300 mg/24 hrs of urine or 1 + or more by dipstick
  • Urine protein: Creatinine ratio >0.3 = Proteinuria
  • Early onset: <34 weeks of pregnancy
  • Late onset: >34 weeks of pregnancy

Eclampsia

Convulsion (generalized tonic-clonic convulsions) + Hypertension

Chronic Hypertension

Pre-existing hypertension presenting in early pregnancy

  • Essential hypertension
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Pheochromocytoma

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is gravida 1, para 1, presents with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 1.5 months. What is the initial investigation of choice?
A 32-week pregnant woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
In which of the following scenarios is early cord clamping typically performed?

A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents for routine prenatal care. Her blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, and routine laboratory studies reveal a platelet count of 120,000/µL. She is asymptomatic and has no history of bleeding disorders.What is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
Which of the following does not cause polyhydramnios?
questions.explanation:
Condition

AFI Range

Description

Normal

5-24 cm

Associated with normal fetal well-being.

Oligohydramnios

< 5 cm

Indicates lower-than-normal amniotic fluid volume and may lead to fetal growth restriction.

Polyhydramnios

> 24 cm

Indicates excessive amniotic fluid accumulation, increasing the risk of preterm labour, placental abruption, and umbilical cord complications.

Causes

Polyhydramnios

Oligohydramnios

Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) (Option B)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Esophageal atresia (Option C)
  • Neural tube defects (Option A)
  • Renal agenesis
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Fetal growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Amnion nodosum

Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Preeclampsia
  • Placental insufficiency

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

Placental abruption

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the sign seen on the given USG?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Spina bifida

Ultrasound findings in spina bifida

Cranial abnormalities

  • Cisterna magna obliteration
  • Banana sign: Compression or flattening of posterior cerebellar surface, giving a crescentic appearance
  • Lemon sign: Concave deformity of the frontal bones
  • Hydrocephaly

Fetal face

  • Cleft lip
  • Cleft palate

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks + 6 days with labour pains. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 3cm dilated and 60% effaced. The fetal head is at -3 station and membranes are felt as a bag of worms beneath the head. What is the appropriate course of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse

options.label: B
options.text: Proceed with emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)

questions.correct_answer: B. Proceed with emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)
questions.explanation:
Living baby

Definitive treatment

 

Cesarean Section (Best option for mature, living babies)

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Possible:
  • Head Engaged: Complete delivery with forceps (ventouse is less ideal).
  • Breech Presentation: Complete delivery by breech extraction.

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Not Possible

 
  • Minimise cord pressure until definitive treatment or transfer to a suitable hospital.
  • Stop any ongoing oxytocin infusion.
  • Bladder Filling: Use a Foley catheter to fill the bladder with 400–750 mL fluid—empty the bladder before cesarean delivery.
  • Postural Treatment: Use an elevated Sims position with a pillow or wedge
  • Cord Replacement: Place the cord back into the vagina to reduce vasospasm.

Baby Dead

 

Allow labour to proceed for spontaneous delivery.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant female in her first trimester presents to the OPD for a regular antenatal checkup. During blood type screening, potential ABO incompatibility is discussed. The healthcare provider explains that certain antibody types are less concerning than others during pregnancy. ABO incompatibility does not occur due to which antibody in her case?

A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. Fetal movements are normal on examination, fetal parts are not easily felt, and fetal heartbeat is heard but muffled. Her symphysis-fundal height is 41 cm. Her abdomen is tense but not tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Causes

Polyhydramnios

Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia) (Option A)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Hydrops fetalis

Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between:
questions.explanation:
mg/dL

mmol/litre

Fasting

≤ 92

5.1

1 hour

≤ 180

10.1

2 hours

≤ 153

8.5

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the perimortem cesarean section?
questions.explanation:
Risk of Lower Uterine Segment Complications
  • Densely adherent bladder from previous surgery.
  • Leiomyoma in the lower uterine segment.
  • Cervical cancer involvement.
  • Previous radical trachelectomy for cervical cancer.

Placenta-Related Issues
  • Placenta previa with anterior implantation.
  • Placenta accreta syndrome.

Maternal Obesity
  • Massive obesity that prevents safe access to the lower uterine segment.

Fetal Indications
  • Transverse fetal lie with ruptured membrane and impacted shoulder.
  • Transverse lie with the back-down position.
  • Very small or breech fetus.
  • Small fetal head entrapped by contracting uterine fundus following membrane rupture.
  • Multiple fetuses that may be malpositioned or preterm.
  • Large fetal malformation or conjoined twins requiring extra space.

Perimortem Mother
  • In cases of maternal cardiac arrest where immediate delivery is necessary to save the fetus, a classical cesarean section is often performed due to the urgency and limited time.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 35 weeks + 5 days gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is in labor pain. Examination of the cervix shows a 3 cm dilatation with a bag of liquor. What is the appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete

options.label: D
options.text: Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation

  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management

  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management

  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation.

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  1. HELLP syndrome
  2. Pulmonary edema
  3. Eclampsia
  4. Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  5. Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  6. Worsening renal function
  7. Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  8. Visual disturbances
  9. Motor deficits
  10. Altered sensorium
  11. Stroke
  12. Myocardial infarction
  1. Abnormal fetal testing
  2. Fetal death
  3. Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  4. Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management

  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of diabetes in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Elective C-section has no role in reducing the incidence of brachial plexus injury.

options.label: B
options.text: In a patient being planned for induction of labor, the night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld.

options.label: C
options.text: In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/hr till the RBS is >100 mg%.

options.label: D
options.text: Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 hr postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 hrs postprandial- 120 mg%.

questions.correct_answer: A. Elective C-section has no role in reducing the incidence of brachial plexus injury.

questions.text: What is the initial indication of magnesium sulfate toxicity in a woman undergoing treatment for eclampsia?
questions.explanation:
Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar or knee-jerk reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ Interpretation of OGTT
  • ➤ Interpretation of OGTT
  • ➤ A curve is plotted by placing time on the X-axis and plasma glucose level on the Y-axis, referred to as the Glucose Tolerance Curve (GTC).
  • ➤ 1. Normal Response A typical normal response includes the following features:
  • ➤ 1. Normal Response
  • ➤ Initial fasting glucose is within normal limits. The highest peak value is reached within 1 hour. The highest value does not exceed the renal threshold (160–180 mg/dl). Fasting glucose levels are restored within 2–2.5 hours. No glucose or ketone bodies are detected in any urine specimen.
  • ➤ Initial fasting glucose is within normal limits.
  • ➤ The highest peak value is reached within 1 hour.
  • ➤ The highest value does not exceed the renal threshold (160–180 mg/dl).
  • ➤ Fasting glucose levels are restored within 2–2.5 hours.
  • ➤ No glucose or ketone bodies are detected in any urine specimen.
  • ➤ 2. Response of Diabetic Patients Features include:
  • ➤ 2. Response of Diabetic Patients
  • ➤ Fasting blood glucose is elevated above 110 mg/dl. The highest value is reached after 1–1.5 hours. The highest value exceeds the renal threshold. The blood glucose level does not return to fasting levels within 2.5 hours (most characteristic feature of DM). Urine samples always contain glucose (except in chronic diabetes or nephritis with raised renal thresholds).
  • ➤ Fasting blood glucose is elevated above 110 mg/dl.
  • ➤ The highest value is reached after 1–1.5 hours.
  • ➤ The highest value exceeds the renal threshold.
  • ➤ The blood glucose level does not return to fasting levels within 2.5 hours (most characteristic feature of DM).
  • ➤ Urine samples always contain glucose (except in chronic diabetes or nephritis with raised renal thresholds).
  • ➤ Severity of Diabetic Curves:
  • ➤ Mildly diabetic curve Moderately severe diabetic curve Severe diabetic curve
  • ➤ Mildly diabetic curve
  • ➤ Moderately severe diabetic curve
  • ➤ Severe diabetic curve
  • ➤ 3. Lag Curve for Hyperglycemia Features include:
  • ➤ 3. Lag Curve for Hyperglycemia
  • ➤ Fasting glucose level is normal. Glucose rises rapidly within ½ to 1 hour, exceeding the renal threshold, leading to glucose in urine specimens. Rapid and complete return to normal values.
  • ➤ Fasting glucose level is normal.
  • ➤ Glucose rises rapidly within ½ to 1 hour, exceeding the renal threshold, leading to glucose in urine specimens.
  • ➤ Rapid and complete return to normal values.
  • ➤ Conditions Associated:
  • ➤ Hyperthyroidism Pregnancy Early diabetes
  • ➤ 4. Curve for Renal Glycosuria
  • ➤ 4. Curve for Renal Glycosuria
  • ➤ Glucose appears in the urine at levels of blood glucose much below the renal threshold. Patients who show no glucosuria when fasting may have glycosuria when blood glucose is raised.
  • ➤ Glucose appears in the urine at levels of blood glucose much below the renal threshold.
  • ➤ Patients who show no glucosuria when fasting may have glycosuria when blood glucose is raised.
  • ➤ It may be seen in:
  • ➤ Renal disease and pregnancy Early diabetes
  • ➤ Renal disease and pregnancy
  • ➤ Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group of India (DIPSI) Guidelines
  • ➤ Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group of India (DIPSI) Guidelines
  • ➤ Procedure : Non-fasting woman is given a 75 gm glucose load. Assessment: Blood sugar levels are measured after 2 hours.
  • ➤ Procedure : Non-fasting woman is given a 75 gm glucose load.
  • ➤ Assessment: Blood sugar levels are measured after 2 hours.
  • ➤ Sugar Value Interpretation >200 mg/dl Diabetes Mellitus (DM) 140–200 mg/dl DGGT (Deranged Gestational Glucose Tolerance) >120 mg/dl Indicates further investigation needed

  • ➤ >200 mg/dl Diabetes Mellitus (DM)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO4 is false?

options.label: A
options.text: MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose-dependent

options.label: B
options.text: MgSO4 is continued up to 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure

options.label: C
options.text: It has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex, thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

options.label: D
options.text: In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.correct_answer: C. It has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex, thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
questions.explanation:
MOA
  • NMDA Receptor Blockade
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: reduces calcium influx into neurons.
  • Vasodilation: Improves cerebral blood flow and reduces cerebral edema, dilates uterine arteries, increases endothelial prostacyclin production and inhibits platelet activation.

Uses
  • Prevent seizures in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia.
  • Prevent recurrent seizures in eclampsia.
  • Tocolytic effect (delaying preterm labor)
  • Neuroprotective: Protects the preterm baby's brain from damage by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy

Therapeutic Range

To control fits the optimum serum magnesium is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L). Deep tendon reflex loss at 9 mg/dL (>7 mEq/L).

C/I

Myasthenia gravis, hypocalcemia, moderate-to-severe renal failure, cardiac ischemia, heart block, myocarditis.

Administration and Dosage

Administer: Intravenously or intramuscularly.

  • Loading dose: 4–6 g IV over 20–30 minutes. (Zuspan or Sibai regimen)
  • Maintenance: 1–2 g/hour IV. Monitor urine output and reflexes.

Dosage Adjustment

Adjust for renal dysfunction.

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Pritchard

(IV and IM)
  • Administer 4 g IV over 3-5 mins (20 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution)
  • Follow with 10 g of 50% MgSO4 solution: 5 g (10 mL of 50% solution) in each buttock as deep IM injection with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in the same syringe.
  • 5g IM with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in alternate buttocks every 4 hours; continue for 24 hours after birth or last convulsion

Zuspan

(IV only)
  • Administer 4-6 g IV over 15- 20 mins (20 mL of 20% magnesium sulfate solution).
  • If convulsions recur after 15 mins, give 2g IV (10 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution) over 5 mins.
  • 1-2 g IV infusion per hour (5 mL of 20% solution); continue for 24 hours after childbirth or last convulsion

Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest
